name: Sanjeev Kapoor
bio: Kapoor was born in April 1964 in Ambala and spent his childhood in multiple North Indian cities. He began his career in the hospitality industry in 1984 after completing the Diploma in Hotel Management from the Institute of Hotel Management Catering & Nutrition, Pusa, New Delhi.
ingredients1: 2 lbs boneless chicken breasts,1 cup plain yogurt,1 tbsp ginger paste,1 tbsp garlic paste,1 tsp cumin powder,1 tsp coriander powder,1 tsp garam masala
method1: In a large bowl, whisk together the yogurt ginger paste, garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, garam masala turmeric powder and salt.        Add the chicken to the bowl and mix well to coat Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes or overnight.In a large skillet, melt the butter over medium heat.Add the marinated chicken and cook until browned on all s_ides.Add the tomato puree and simmer for 10-15 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through. Stir in the heavy cream and cook for an additional 5 minutes. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves and serve with rice or naan bread.
ingredients2: Soya granules soaked 2 cupFresh breadcrumbs 1 cup,Ginger,piece sliced 1/2 inch,Garlic finely chopped 1 teaspoon,Red chilli powder 1 teaspoon
method2: Place soya granules in a chopper, add fresh breadcrumbs, ginger, garlic, ½ tsp red chilli powder, chaat masala, green chilli paste, salt, 2 tbsps water and chop finely.Transfer the mixture into a bowl, add cornflour and mix well.Heat oil in a non-stick pan.Div_ide the mixture into 4 equal portions and shape each into an oval chop. Pierce an ice cream stick at one end of each chop. Smoothen and place in the pan.
ingredients3: Potatoes boiled and mashed 5-6,French beans blanched and chopped 5-6,Beetroot grated 1 medium,Green peas blanched and crushed 1/2 cup,Oil 2 tablespo to shallow fry,Cumin seeds 1/2 teaspoon,Ginger finely chopped 1 inch piece

name: Ranveer Brar
bio: He d_id his schooling from HAL school Lucknow. His passion to learn the art led him to volunteer as an apprentice to one of them, Munir Ustad. Though his family initially resisted, they finally gave in, leading Brar to join Institute of Hotel Management, Lucknow, for a more formal initiation into the culinary world.
